ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn to think about game theory in a more formal setting.

The first half was the basics such as different representations of games, backward induction, dominance, Nash equilibrium, refinements of the solution concept, and proof of existence of a NE. The second half was applications, repeated games, knowledge and beliefs, Bayes-Nash equilibrium, signal games and Perfect Bayesian equilibrium, and finally Sequential equilibrium.
I learned how to solve a number of games.
Learnt about the various ways to think about strategically optimal behavior in games
Learning about extensive form and normal form games, how to set up strategic games.
I learned a bit about many complex topics in game theory. I honestly think the course gave me a look into grad school because of the way it was taught.
How to model and solve games that were: simultaneous, sequential, had perfect information, had imperfect information, had unknown preferences, had different types.
Terrible, terrible, terrible course. Do not take unless needed, and even then just switch your major to Math / CS. Math / Econ is useless, CS / Econ isn't as cool as you think it is.

You learn to draw things in Extensive Form and make assumptions about people's decisions for no real reason. Most of the class can be boiled down to common sense, but instead we use fancy mathematical notation to say that person A prefers $10 more than $9. Game Theory in itself is not especially interesting, but this class is only taken by people who have to take it. One additional skill you learn is to stop caring towards the end, when the class is so far removed from everything else (problem sets, exams), and you end up wasting 2h 30m of your week on notation.

I am a math and physics person -- not an economics person -- and I feel like I learned a whole new way of thinking! Kind of in the same way that physics classes are just math but with clever tricks thrown in that are specialized to the field. This class just felt like a really cool math class that was specialized to the field of game theory. Loved it.
Various solution concepts like Nash equilibrium, subgame perfect equilibrium, perfect Bayesian equilibrium, etc. How to solve for such equilibria, and some proofs of existence.
Knowledge of game theory concepts, including Nash equilibrium, bargaining, knowledge, and auctions.
I learned how to think about and solve games. It challenged and improved my abilities to problem solve.
A mathematically rigorous introduction to the field of game theory

A breathtaking introduction to game theory/graduate-level micro. We talked about solution concepts such as iterative deletion of strictly dominant strategies, Nash equilibrium, correlated equilibrium, subgame perfect Nash, Bayesian Nash, Perfect Bayesian Nash, and sequential equilibrium. As an econ math major, I thoroughly enjoyed the proofs too (existence of NE, separating hyperplane theorems, etc).
Nothing applicable to any non-academic role. If it was more understandable, it might be interesting. However, it still wouldn't be useful for most jobs. Way too many proofs in this class.
Game theory in a rigorous mathematical context.
The skill of giving up
Introduction to game theory at a pretty detailed level

You do learn a lot of game theory in this class. Examples include strategies (pure/mixed), rationality, dominance, Nash equilibria, subgames, sub game-perfect NE, correlated equilibria, Bayesian NE, perfect Bayesian NE, sequential equilibria, bargaining and auctions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The prof is cool and knowledgeable. The course is too math involved. Some lectures he just covers a single proof.

Strengths: when the ideas come together at the end, it's pretty cool but... Weaknesses: ... at what cost??? Extremely challenging. Prof Horner moves fast and is tough. Homework feels impossible some weeks, either because you have no idea how to even start to prove something or you have to solve some ridiculous equations (learn to use mathematica for these). In general, the class is a weird mix between trying to be super rigorous in the math and actually solving games. Class is mostly theoretical while homework can get really computational. Also, office hours and section were Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, while psets would usually come out Thursday and be due Tuesday. Thus we were on our own.
This course was difficult but I learned a lot.
Don't take this class unless you have to for the CS Econ Major. It's ridiculously hard

I felt like this course was designed to feel bad and make students feel like they had little direction. In particular, office hours with the professor and TA almost always occurred AFTER problem sets were due, leaving students with little guidance on working through different questions.

This is a difficult course. I think the content covered is potentially useful if you're doing a high level finance or quant position, or if you're going to grad school. Otherwise, this goes more in depth than necessary. I thought the topics were interesting, but I felt like we moved through them too quickly to really grasp them. I think lectures should have had more application, because lectures were mostly theorems or proofs and then I had no idea what I was doing on homework and exams.

Strengths: Hrner is a really incredible instructor and I'd take this course for his teaching alone. I also felt that the problem sets were relevant to what we did in class and really pushed how much I understood the material.
Weaknesses: The exams. I just felt like there was no way I could be prepared for the exams, in particular the final after I had experienced the midterm. I had put in all the effort I could into doing practice problems from psets and past exams, but I felt really unable to apply that knowledge in the exam itself, which felt really disheartening.
Honestly, everything can be improved. garbage

Strengths: Prof. Horner is quite kind and enjoyable lecturer. TAs, especially Alex, were also helpful.

Weaknesses: While Professor Horner is an amiable and entertaining lecturer, the material covered in the course lacks interest, and the problem sets fail to facilitate meaningful learning. Professor Horner's lectures were often tangential and focused on complex theorems that left many of us, particularly those of us majoring in Computer Science and Economics (half the class), feeling left out and unengaged. Moreover, the problem sets assigned in the course were often on unrelated topics, leading to confusion and frustration. The lack of feedback on problem sets was another significant issue that further hampered our learning. Furthermore, the class's morale was noticeably poor, and this was compounded by the difficulty of the exams.

To improve the course, I suggest Professor Horner should focus on delivering lectures that are more relatable and directly tied to the course material. Additionally, assigning problem sets that are better aligned with the lecture topics and scheduling office hours at times that are more convenient for all students would be helpful. Providing prompt feedback on the problem sets would also be valuable in aiding our learning and understanding of the material. Finally, it would be beneficial to revisit the exam difficulty to ensure that they accurately reflect the course's content and are reasonably challenging for students to complete. Simply put, the class median on the midterm should not have been less than 50%.
Nothing was ever really explained in lecture that was relevant to the problem sets or exams. In general not was much explained in lecture at all.

There was a huge gap between the material covered in lecture and the weekly psets. There was very little support -- office hours were typically held after the psets were due. The psets and exams were unfair in terms of level of difficulty.

I think this class does a good job getting students to think. I think many of the homework problems were interesting, and Professor Horner was an engaging lecturer. However, I don't think that the lectures or notes made feel prepared to do the homework or especially the exams. Not enough example problems were given, and the exams were too time pressured. Additionally, psets were often posted after both section and office hours had passed, meaning we had little time and not much outside support to complete psets that were intentionally very difficult.
The lectures are engaging and the material is very interesting. The exams were a bit overwhelming given their difficulty level.

Covers a good deal of material and some very interesting concepts. However, it would be helpful if the lectures included some more "worked examples," similar to content that would show up on problem sets / exams.

Strengths: The material is fascinating and Professor Horner is a great lecturer. Weaknesses: This class was NOT set up to facilitate student learning. Problem sets were usually released on Thursday nights and due on Tuesday in class, but TA sessions and office hours were held on Tues-Thurs. The questions could be nearly impossible, which meant that most of the time, I could only guess how to solve them, and it was only a week or two later when the solutions came out that I could see what I should have done. There was so much material, and I never knew what I was expected to learn. I thought I would have clarity after the midterm, but it was so ridiculously difficult and curved so intensely that I just continued the semester relying on the fact that problem sets were graded on completion. Office hours should be available to help students with the problem sets, and there needs to be a clearer understanding of what students are expected to learn.

Strengths  extremely well thought out, thorough proprietary lecture notes, top tier lecturer

No weaknesses  except its hard!! Make sure this class is for you
Strengths: Horner, Horner, Horner. Cannot say enough about a professor who never makes a mistake on the board without any notes...

This course is far too abstract. This course should NOT be a requirement for cs econ. It could be improved by being taught more slowly, with more emphasis on content that will actually be on the psets and exams. 

Many turned to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ceOF4yOAnXM&list=PLcrc6i6xwaQRP-e4fCBAnOmkbn860TX1_ for much clearer explanations and other help.

The lectures are not helpful - examples would be appreciated instead of a ton of nonsense mathematical expressions. It's such a difficult class - avoid at all cost. You will pour hours and hours into this class and still fail. Average for midterm is a 40% and average for a final is also around 40.

Do not. DONT. AVOID. Run. Please don't. Listen to me. Do not. This class is bad. Don't don't don't. Worst class ever. 323 is the easiest and best class at Yale in comparison. This is just a euphemistic way of how little you should think of considering taking this class.
I loved the material and the challenge of the class, and constantly felt that I was exploring new ways to think about games and its applications

Strengths: the professor and teaching staff are very knowledgable in the material, which you will end up learning decently well by the end of the course. The lectures notes are also helpful. The psets do prepare you decently well for the exam material. Teaching staff were relatively responsive to emails
Weaknesses: The lectures are very difficult to understand at times, mostly because they are very notation and theory-heavy. It was very easy for me to get so lost in the mathematical notation in class that I would completely miss out on the big picture b/c we would spend 45+ minutes of class talking about the justification for a concept w/o me fulling understand what the concept was to begin with. In addition, the timing of homeworks and office hours was pretty bad in my iteration of the class. Office hours were held on Wednesday and Thursdays, but homeworks often wouldn't be released until Thursday (at the earliest) and due next Tuesday, meaning that we would get a maximum of one office hours to ask questions (and at the beginning of the year, some homeworks weren't released until Friday/Saturday if I recall correctly, which would lead to no office hours before homework was due). Since the material in class is so theory-heavy, it was often difficult to apply any those concepts to the homeworks and most of the material ended up being self-taught through the lectures notes and other resources online. Exams were also notoriously difficult (in my opinion, not necessarily because the problems themselves were extremely difficult but because of the amount of problems you were expected to solve in the short time spans they gave for both exams) with averages hovering around 40% for both the midterm and final

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Don't take it unless you need it. 159 covers similar topics and is more fun and less math involved.
No. Needlessly tough and tedious. Save some sleep on Monday nights.
I would recommend the course to people who like econ and proofs.
NO! Don't take this class unless you have to! The exams and problem sets were insanely tough.
If you enjoy theoretical math and economic thinking, yes. The actual content is interesting, but the organization and teaching style was particularly difficult.
I think I'd only recommend it if it's required. It's a difficult course and you really need to be engaged and do extra work to succeed in the course.

Hm, I would if Hrner is teaching it. But even then I would caution that you have to be ready to commit a significant number of hours to the homework each week, and if you're not ready or expecting that commitment, you would resent the course for making you put in so much effort to learn.
No, unless you're willing to not understand a single concept about what is going on

While I believe that this course may not be suitable for CS/Econ majors due to its intensity and focus on mathematical theorems, it is a requirement. However, I am pleased to hear that an alternative may be available soon. For Math/Econ students, the course seems to be more aligned with their background and interests, and I noticed that they performed better overall. However, for those of us without a strong background in mathematics, it was challenging to keep up with the pace and understand the concepts, which was frustrating.

I suggest that the course could be improved by providing more guidance and support to students who may not have the same level of mathematical proficiency. This could be achieved by offering additional resources such as tutorials or workshops. Moreover, the course material could be presented in a way that is more accessible and engaging for all students, regardless of their background. Finally, I would recommend that the course be reviewed to ensure that it meets the needs of all students who are required to take it.

If you are neither CS/Econ nor Math/Econ, do NOT take this class. It is not worth it and if you really want to learn this content then read Rubinstein's "A Course in Game Theory" and save yourself the struggle and heartbreak that comes with taking this class.
Yes, with this professor (Johannes Horner) specifically. His exams are a bit sadistic but he's a great lecturer, very smart and engaging.
Never.
No, unless required for their major.

Only if you it is required. Although it is interesting in parts and I think the problems would be fun to do without time and academic pressure, it is a lot of work and I did not feel that the class prepared me for the exams.

Yes, definitely, but with some caveats. The course is taught very well, the material is fascinating (this is probably the only undergraduate economics course at Yale that teaches the proofs of i.e. Brouwer's fixed point theorem and the existence of Nash equilibrium) and Horner is a very clear and engaging lecturer. That being said, the workload is overwhelming at times, with very long problem sets and very challenging exams. So yes, I'd recommend the course, but keep that in mind when choosing when to take it and what other courses to take concurrently.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in game theory and the mathematical concepts behind many foundational game theory principles.

My feelings about this course are complicated, but in short, no I would not recommend it. Horner is a fantastic lecturer, he is very well versed in the material and might be one the best living theorists, but pain associated with every other part of the course makes it very hard to recommend. The problem sets are weekly, very hard (think 230/231), often posted late, and the solution concepts are almost never taught in lecture/notesmeaning that you must go either to the TAs office hours (which are most often moved or cancelled) or read another textbook. Problem set content is therefore often very different from the exams (or at least the final, he gave us the same exam as the PhD students for the midterm), which makes it hard to prepare for the quick calculations required to do well. This is exacerbated by the fact that many of the midterm and final answer keys had incorrect answers, since those practice exams are the only place to find similar problems outside of a third party. Overall I would say take the course if you feel up for the challenge, but (especially if you have another option in your major) it is very hard to recommend it over 159.

I would never recommend this class to another student. The lack of support and the impossibility of problem sets and exams meant that the class is a little demoralizing. If you have the option, take the game theory class that everyone loves. It sometimes felt as if this class was designed to be hard and for students to struggle rather than designed to challenge students and provide them with an in-depth understanding of game theory. Game theory is fun, but this class is awful.
Yes  with sufficient math background

Disclaimer: my review only applies if Horner is teaching again ---------------------------

You will likely see a lot of negative reviews on this page (rightfully so) because this is a hard class and the exams are very demoralizing. I think this mainly stems from how this class is advertised - not only does it require time but compared to ECON 350 (let alone other econ classes) it also requires a lot math (probability and analysis at the very least), and not just confidence in math. Without the prereqs I would imagine one to do fine in some cases but you might be better off taking 159 instead. ---------------------------

But! If you are math or econ-math or have the math background, I cannot recommend this class more and I for once in my yale career feel compelled to write an evaluation more than three sentences. There are plenty great things to be said about 159 but I imagine this class will give you much more. Even with games of perfect information (which 159 spends majority if not all of its time on and we spent half before moving onto Bayesian stuff), correlated equilibrium and minimax theorems are such cool ways to think about games. As Horner said, although exams do not involve proofs, how can a math-econ game theory class not cover the proof of the existence of Nash equilibrium? Speaking of exams and psets, while I too feel that they are unnecessarily hard, I'm sure the curve is very generous. Overall, this class is the highlight of my semester and I would recommend you to shop it if you have the math prereqs!
Don't take this unless you have to. I've heard that Economics and Computation is much better, for the cs econ joint majors.

Not if you don't have to. Each weekly pset takes so incredibly long and we are not given enough time to complete them so most people just put bs on paper. Grading on pset is lenient though. Advice: Don't spend too much time on them, not worth it

Truly one of the classes that Yale offers. 

We definitely had a professor. The professor used a chalk piece to imprint some chalk remains on the board while using his vocal chords to produce sounds that students listened to. Some define this as teaching. This is also a class where you receive problem sets that contained words similar to those uttered by the professor in these periods of time that some define as a class. Definitely, some of the problem sets I have done in my life. 

Undoubtedly, this course can be counted among the many that have taken place within the hallowed halls of Yale. The classroom itself had four walls, a ceiling, and a floor, as one would expect from such an esteemed institution. It was within this space that students convened, sitting on chairs and placing their belongings on flat surfaces known as tables or desks.

During these moments of group gathering, which could be referred to as "lectures," the professor ensured that information was transmitted through a process that some may describe as "education." As students, we were not only given the opportunity to observe the professor's skillful manipulation of chalk but also to hear the utterances that emanated from his mouth. These utterances, which could be classified as words, were then assembled into sentences, followed by paragraphs  a true testament to the mastery of the English language.

The course materials, often referred to as "readings," contained an assortment of letters, which when read, were said to impart knowledge to the reader. This knowledge was, a non-negative number of times, related to the content of the lectures and problem sets.

Furthermore, the course offered a unique opportunity to interact with fellow students, who could be identified by their presence in the same room at the same time, all sharing a common goal: to complete the course requirements.

As the semester progressed, the culmination of these educational components was measured through two significant events: the midterm and the final exam. These exams consisted of questions and problems that required a written response. The class average, a number impressively greater than 0%, served as an indisputable testament to the efficacy of this learning experience.

In summary, out of all the classes I have taken at Yale, this has truly been one of them.
Yes, it is truly an exciting and rewarding class, especially for those who are more mathematically inclined. The work may be difficult, but it really made me feel confident in my abilities

There is not much reason to take this class unless you are required to take it or you just love both math and game theory (I fell into the former category until CS+Econ no longer required 351 after I'd already taken it). You and your mental health are likely to be better served taking 159 if you want to learn game theory
